doc.field: The Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
creation: 1785; alteration: 1803; alteration: 1852-1854; alteration: 1898; alteration: 1929; alteration: 1934; alteration: 1950; alteration: 1953

Farmington Country Club in 1929--Warner Wood Home 1877--Joseph Miller owner 1860 then to sister Mary Ann Wood Harper as her home-- Gen Bernard Peyton Home 1852 --George Divers Home 1785--Francis Jerdone (Tory) owner 1758--Michael Holland Patent 1744

Pre 1803 2/3 Georgian: 2 Story Brick, Flemish Bond, Stone Underpining, Vertical Hand-carved Swashed Banisters, Rose Head Nails, Reciprocating Saw Marks, Flat Cyma Trim, Transom with Sidelights, HL Hinges, Vertical Wood Batten Door, 4 Panel Door, Diagonally-set Wood Bars in Cellar Transom; 1803 Octagonal Portion: 2 Story Brick, Tetrastyle Portico, Lunette in Tympanum, Flemish Bond, 3 Course Americaond, Figural Spaces, Widows Walk, Hipped Roof, Flemish Bond, 3 Course American Bond, Brick Vaulted Wine Cellar, Diagonally-set Wood Bars in Cellar Transom, Stone Underpinning, Segmental Wood Cellar Window, Brick Ceiling Insulation in Cellar, Reciprocating Saw Marks, Flat Cyma Trim, Cyma Reversa Trim, 4 Panel Door with Applied Moldings, 6 Panel Doors,Triple Hung Sash, 6/6/6, Bulls-eye Windows, Blinds; Outbuildings: Kitchen, Icehouse, Log Slave Quarters, Stone Stables, Cemetery; Slave Quarters: Flemish Bond, 3 Course American Bond, 9/9

Thomas Jefferson, Architect 1803--Edmund Campbell, Architect 1929; Marshall Wells & Pruitt and Brown, Architects 1934--Marshall Wells, Architect 1950; Floyd Johnson, Architect 1953--Frederick Nichols, Architect 20th century
survey data: National Register of Historic Places--Virginia Landmarks Register--MD--Virginia Road Traces
Divers claim--Jefferson addition--North Portico--West Addition--Converted into country club--Dining Room, Terrace Room--Tornado damage in wing, Ballroom, Taproom, Peacock Alley--Entrance
